It doesn't have any groundbreaking additions, but the game still is a very interesting choice for those looking for a new 2D fighter, or for those who missed the previous version. Or, of course, for the hardcore fans of the franchise.

With combos and accessibility akin to Dragon Ball FighterZ and deep, intricate mechanics like Tekken and Injustice, it truly caters to whoever chooses to pick up a controller. A diverse and unique cast, an electric soundtrack and exciting visuals make for ferocious fights, and while the competition is hot in the fighting game genre right now it’s undoubtedly worth a peek.
Quick on the attack and heavy on style, Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late[st] is a fighting game that requires an equal mix of brawn and brain to survive its unique take on all-or-nothing fisticuffs.

Under Night In-Birth Exe: Late[st] brings new additions to the table, but doesn’t offer massive improvements over the games that came before it. It’s very much a reminder of a bygone era where an incremental upgrade led to a “new” entry in a series, but this does at least include quality of life improvements thanks to the overhauled storyline presentation. Anyone who has a prior version of the game will know what they’re getting into here, while newcomers should have a blast if they enjoy a faster-paced Guilty Gear-style affair.

In a crowded period for fighting games, French-Bread has come out with a very strong contender that should not be overlooked. Although Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late[st] is a port instead of an entirely brand new title, there is enough added here - and the game is that good - that it deserves all the attention it gets. Dedicated fans will appreciate the comprehensive chronicle mode that addresses the previous version's shortcomings, whilst the level of depth gone into enabling both casual and long-time fighting players to get invested thanks to the excellent tutorial and mission modes contributes to the overall satisfyingly packed range of content. A balanced cast and intricate combat system top off this stylish anime fighter.
Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late[st] is a great middle ground between the Street Fighters and the anime fighters that exist today with a deep and yet accessible gameplay and great tutorial.

Fantastic. The Vorpal system is a clever twist on the format, adding a neat extra layer of strategy to the game, but it's the cast that really makes Under Night In-Birth stand out. There's so much love and creativity gone into the roster, and that, more than anything else, will make or break a fighting game.

Under Night In-Birth Exe Night: Late[st] is a fighting game based on a solid gameplay and able to offer a great challenge. Despite the fact that it provides a good support to newcomers, the game only offers its best if you can fully master the intense and excited rhythms of the combat system. 2D graphic and the typical Japanese character design are an added value or a minor flaw, depending on your taste. In any case, we're facing a carefully, crafted game, which certainly deserves a chance if you're a fan of the genre.
Decent retro beat-em-up with an interesting battle system. But you’ll have to invest some time to understand and use all the subtleties it has to offer.

Under Night In-Birth Late[st] is the complete package for fighting game fans, with the visual novel-like story being the only potential let down for anyone that isn’t used to how Arc System Works do things. It’s even worth buying, despite the excellent recent fighting game releases, because the combo flexibility and accessibility for both experienced and inexperienced fighting game fans are fairly unique even among fighters.
Good fighting game that may be too ugly for a 2018 fighter, but manages to entertain during a substantial amount of time.

Under Night's biggest problem is that it never truly feels like a PlayStation 4 game, due to mediocre graphics and a story that never manages to truly take off. However, if you're not all that bothered by this, the game's unique characters and fleshed out online modes will keep you busy for a long time to come.

When it comes to accessible 2D fighting, Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late[st] is a worthwhile game that's sure to provide hours of enjoyable combat. Just don't expect any big surprises if you already played the original game.

Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late[st] should satisfy fans of the fighting genre, if they are willing to look past its flaws and spend time perfecting the art of combat for the game's sometimes shaky online mode. As a single player experience, it is well-suited for a couple of friends to pass the time thanks to being fun and accessible.
This "Late[st]" version of Under Night In-Birth EXE adds some stuff to a very cool and technical fighting game that every fan of the genre should try.

Under Night In-Birth EXE: Late (ST) is a deep and complex fighting game which gives players the tools to learn and master its systems and mechanics. The game however, is showing its age with ugly level design and boring menus. Whilst gameplay should come first, there are other fighters out there that are more of a complete package.
There’s no way this will ever be a mainstream fighting game, but it’s still a blast to play.

With Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late, we've got another deep Japanese fighting experience on the PS4. It doesn’t have the looks to go toe-to-toe with some of the shinier games out there, but as Han Solo said, "she might not look like much, but she’s got it where is counts". If you can get past the mad title, this is a portal through which to jump in to the virtually endless realm of combat experimentation.

Under Night In-Birth:Exe Late[st] is a game showing its age but the complexity of its systems continue to shine. A diverse roster should hopefully be complimented by a burgeoning online community. As it is, there's plenty of single-player content, even if the AI is a touch predictable. There's a likeable game at the heart of this with enjoyable combat. I just wish more was put into the presentation.

Under Night In-Birth Exe: Late[st] proposes a solid and not prohibitive combat system. Thanks to the matchmaking, and stability problems that we found during online matches and also to the not so high quality of all the game modes, we can say that Under Night In-Birth Exe: Late[st] is a step below the other Arc System works’ productions.

Under Night In-Birth Exe: Late[st] is an excellent fighting game, but if you’ve already played through Exe: Late on the PS3, there’s not much here to entice you to upgrade. The new Chronicles Mode is ultimately a disappointing slog. While there are two new characters to learn and master, with the current fighting game climate, there’s likely not many people you’ll be able to try them out against. It’s a shame, because Exe: Late[st] is a fine fighting game in its own right, but will inevitably be lost in the shuffle.

Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late[st] is a 2D fighting game developed by French Bread, author of Dengeki Bunko: Fighting Climax and Melty Blood, in partnership with Arc System Works, a studio that has a huge experience in fighting games such as the original Guilty Gear series and BlazBlue, as well as Persona 4 Arena Ultimax and most recently Dragon Ball FighterZ. This game is a update of the game Under Night In-Birth Exe:Late.

title: Undertale
summary: Welcome to UNDERTALE. In this RPG, you control a human who falls underground into the world of monsters. Now you must find your way out... or stay trapped forever.
reviews: Though the game does have its shortfalls, like a lackluster tutorial zone and some infuriating boss mechanics, Undertale is undoubtedly a real stroke of genius. The game plays around with conventions and tropes normally associated with RPGs and subverts them in clever ways, all while telling a deeply personal story that everyone can relate to at some point in their lives. Undertale is a game that makes the player feel and think. It’s a game that fills the player with determination, and is most certainly one that you should play.
Undertale never fails to surprise you and unconventional things will happen when you least expect them to.

Undertale is a clever and charming masterpiece, through and through...No game is perfect, but a very rare handful are special, exceptional examples of the best there is to offer, and Undertale stands proudly beside them.

After playing through Undertale on PS4, I’m happy to report that everything was ported over to console perfectly (including the clever takes on saved games and more)...It's a masterfully crafted experience that I won't forget any time soon.

Nearly two years have passed since Undertale originally released, and it still manages to be an incredibly fresh experience. Every battle is a unique puzzle that the player has to solve, and it’s impossible to count how many times I laughed at the bad jokes of Sans. I’ll never see all that the game has to offer, but that’s okay. I’d rather make friends than destroy them.
This game is totally deserving of the hype its received since it first launched on PC two years ago. Although its not the prettiest, it is one of the most original.
Two years old it may be, but Undertale arrives on PS4 feeling as timeless and inventive as ever.
Undertale is the rare RPG that makes you feel tons of different emotions.
It's masterful, and practically unique - which is just about the best way to describe the game as a whole. [Nov 2017, p.88]
A work so genial and original, where the definitions of "right" and "wrong" acquire new meanings, and in which the impact of our decisions takes on a tangible value.

Undertale is landmark RPG for those who appreciate something a little different – a game that wrong foots you and delights with the way it mixes up the tried and tested formula which so many adventure games stick so tightly to. A rare pleasure.
You wouldn't know it with a passing glance, but it's one of the most progressive and innovative RPGs to come in a long time, breaking down tradition for the sake of invention, with great success.

What I'd forgotten since first experiencing the game back in 2015 was that Undertale is more than just internet jokes, amazing music, and crazy boss battles — it's a heartwarming, beautiful, and tearful romp. I said at the beginning there was nothing like Undertale at the time, and there still is nothing else like it. It's hard to explain what makes Undertale so special without spoiling a lot of it, but all you need to know is that this is a modern classic at its most accessible, and it's worthy of your time, whether you're new to the game or returning for another adventure. This review should fill you with determination to play Undertale.
Undertale is a superb indie role-player that proves once again that it’s not graphics that make a game entertaining but gameplay and great ideas.
With all its humour, imagination and raw emotion it is really difficult not to fall in love with Undertale.

Undertale's reputation is a heavy burden when you launch it two years later in a new platform. It isn't flawless at all. The price, taking into consideration it's an English only game, may turn off may people. However, trying to enjoy all of its routes and extremely polished plot and situations is something that is worth while in the long term. Not a game for everyone, that's for sure, but if you see it on sale, is a cultural phenomenon you should try for yourself.

Despite the fact that Undertale didn't tick all my boxes, it was still an enjoyable game. Its visuals and music brought to mind some of my most cherished memories from my formative years, and are top-notch even for games that try to evoke that retro vibe. Its narrative is tongue-in-cheek and consistantly sends surprises the player's way. The game excels at asking players to enjoy it in ways that are incongruous with the traditional way RPGs are designed. Unfortunately, those looking for a more traditional experience may feel short-changed here. The lion's share of the game's character, lore, and emotional impact is experienced by challenging yourself to play the entire game in a completely different fashion.
The negative reviews are just people that love hating over the game that was popular in 2015.
This game is one of the reasons i lost faith in game review websites.

Boy! What an underwhelming and boring amateur load of crap; game looks like like a great game for the atari 2600 and plays like a glorified mini game. And the writing seems taken straight out of a Teletubbys episode or something. Not even that sad about wasting the money. But very upset because the hype was through the roof!

This game is the manifestation of INDIE OVER-HYPE. It's a nice throw back to older JRPG's with some weird old Atari style gameplay. I'd give it a higher score, but it's given so much extra credit for things that really aren't that innovative really blasted my expectations high only to play a good but AVERAGE RPG. This game is nothing special, but it is a good video game, with some good creative ideas. Realistically it's worth trying, but I can't recommend based on it being unrelated to the fake game alluded to in the hype and reviews.
First off, know what you're getting into - this is a 16 bit throwback, text-driven, turn based RPG.  If that doesn't appeal to you, you're not going to enjoy this game.

Undertale is a retro RPG that has all the elements of a great game, but for me ends up with a whole lot of missed potential. The pieces are all there, lovely music, aesthetic, quirkiness, combat system but it all falls short in such a short length game. It doesn't have enough time to flesh out things that could have made it great. Itemization shows promise then falls short, exploration seems enticing at first but is very rarely rewarding. Dialogue seems to have great potential, then gets old. The combat system is really cool, and then doesn't quite add enough new to keep it fresh and exciting. The enemies are unique but ultimately not quite enough are introduced by the end. The only aspect that stays consistently awesome is the music. All the other elements would have you believe at first that this game is the magnificent gem reviewers are raving about, but ultimately are not fleshed out to warrant more than an average score.

Undertale. Well, This game has a simple plot. After a war between Humans and monsters, Humans banished monsters into the underground. You discover the underground and must find a way out. i must give credit to its plot. I enjoyed it . FOR WHAT IT WAS. It gets very limited because of the repetitive gameplay. It does a bad job at mixing it up. I however found some of the characters to be somewhat  not bad. I invested myself into the plot for a bit, and i think it paid off. It doesnt really build up to the final battle, unfortunatly. This game gets a bit quirky at times. Even made me cringe.  Yes, if you ignore all the bad fanart and crappy community cancer, this game does an OK job. Not a game i would recommend to all players, but i somehow got addicted to this game, however i feel like the game is spoiled by its fandom. I never got back to playing it after the fandom spilled out. This game was originally on pc, but then spilled onto Playstation. I don't know why they ported it since this game is a couple years old? I don't know. The visuals gives off the earthbound vibe from like the 1990's. Not saying its a bad thing, it might even be innovative. The soundtrack is good. i recieved it very well and thought it was always fitting, since this was made by one guy. The game is like only 4 HOURS LONG. (Angryjoe would be disappointed). There are "multiple endings", but its just different end text. THATS IT. 4 HOURS FOR THIS?! Very disappointing!  Thats all from me, really.

This is such a sweet indie work of passion. There is genuine quality and dedication put in to this game. If you don't understand this game it does not make it bad. My heroes journey through this game kept me coming back and it never grew boring or soulless. This game has a soul and if you appreciate works of art then this is for you.

As a person who heard and never played Undertale on PC yet had a PS4, I was quite happy to hear the game was coming to the console and the Vita of all things. Hearing about it's achievements and awards it was given by even the most cynical of critics made me wonder much about the world of Undertale, so I was quite excited to jump on it and give it a run through. So does it deserve praise and acclaim then? Absolutely.

I've no idea why the game is received so poorly on PS4 but so well on PC. I can only assume that the PS4 gamers more overwhelmingly look for a streamlined, "exciting" entertainment experience and don't have any appetite to reflect upon the actual contents/story of the game, which is a real shame. Also they might be less used to indie games/games with retro graphics. I don't think anybody who rated the game badly actually even understood what the game is about. They probably just stormed through the game killing everybody they see on sight... exactly the thing the game is making a point about. This game is a meta comment on the state of today's gaming culture. Sadly the ratings here seem to exactly prove why the author wanted to make such a comment in the first place... If somebody played through the story and yet isn't in the least bit moved by it, I can't imagine what kind of person he/she must be in real life... Just horrible. If you at least have some heart then play it and you won't regret it in the slightest. The alternative perspective it provides is incredibly refreshing and touching, though you might not necessarily agree with it. If you only look for the thrills of killing some enemy and never look at the story (which to be fair many modern games just don't give a f*** about), then don't complain after playing it or come here to leave bad ratings.
Ok, let's get the biggest "oh my god!" moment out of the way right at the beginning: In my personal opinion, Undertale is one of the most overrated games of the past few years.

This is an amazing game that is everything I personally want in an RPG: strong characters, doesn't take itself too seriously, uses your choices to greatly effect the game, branching paths, unique combat, clever mechanics, and even has a worthwhile message.  Undertale also has some of the best chiptune music to really give it an interesting feel.  If you haven't played Undertale just yet, I highly recommend that you give it a try.

Undertale is a really cute and quirky game. It's one of those games that can really help to put you in a good mood if you're feeling down because it's (at times quite bizarre) humor. The battle system is super unique and the ability to not kill a single enemy allows for a much different strategy from most games. I can understand how it wouldn't be a game for everyone because if you don't appreciate its quirkiness a lot of the game's humor will be lost on you. It is a little short but it has good replay value and for a cost of $15 dollars you can't expect a game that's the length of Skyrim and at that price you gotta check it out at the very least because it's a truly unique gaming experience!

Undertale is more than just a indie retro-RPG game. Undertale is not about exploration, nice pixel art ou epic combat moments (the boss fights are great btw), Undertale is about characters and the impact of your actions in the setting. If you want a game to get involved with the story and characters, Undertale is the game for you, but if you want sometihing more superficial this is not for you
A genuinely entertaining story, but not much else. I watched a playthrough of the game before I played it, and didn't feel anything rewarding from personally playing the game myself.

This game is a masterpiece of a satire. BUT IT IS A SATIRE. Be wary of that, don't go into this game thinking that it'll change your life, every part is so good. It's not the greatest game ever made. But it's got charm to it, good writing, some intuitive ideas making it feel very fresh and different than anything I have ever played.
A work so genial and original, where the definitions of "right" and "wrong" acquire new meanings, and in which the impact of our decisions takes on a tangible value.
Defines a generation. A masterpiece in videogames.

Undertale is a masterpiece being hated on by people who are desperate to sound interesting. If you love games with deep and interesting stories, charming retro graphics, outstanding music, memorable characters and several mysteries that will stick with you this is your game.
People like to hate for the sake of hating. Undertale is surely a failure of it's own success. This game is good, it deserves much higher score than a 6.2.

If you want your games to actually SAY something and evoke feelings in you, Undertale is where its at. You get attached to all of the characters, the story is great (especially if you're willing to put in the work to discover all of it), combat (or anti-combat?) is fun and engaging. The soundtrack is great as well.

This version of the game also just came out today (as of writing this), isn't on a Nintendo console like BOTW is (not really getting why you even think BOTW and Undertale are similar) and still has a 92 on the PC version.
If you ever thought a masterpiece is not a thing, you were wrong.
This game is just as good the second time through on the PS4 as it was on the PC. The story, characters, music, setting, world... everything is great. 10/10 for Toby Fox and Undertale.

Undertale does this  bizzare and rare thing when you actually like the characters. The game is filled with humour and charm. The soundtrack is AMAZING. The songs are extremely catchy and good.  I am not the biggest fan of turnbased combat, but undertale's combat is so different and fun.

Have you ever noticed how, in a typical RPG (and, now that I think about it, most games in general) battles don’t really mean anything? How many times have you defeated a miniboss, only to have it stand back up and laugh at you, saying “I have underestimated you! You are a worthy opponent! This is not the end! We shall meet again!” and make a getaway? Think about it. How many times do you beat up Balrog in Cave Story only to have him fly away without a scratch? How is Black Knight able to keep running away after Shovel Knight stabs the hell out of him? How come you black out if you lose a Pokémon battle, but none of the other trainers do? And how does the big bad villain always seem to get away, even if their HP hits zero, so they can reappear in the sequel?

This is one of the best modern rpg games to play, taking the Earthbound gameplay and taking it way far away, Undertale have a unique fight system that makes the battle more interactive, you not just receive damage waiting for your next turn, you can dodge the attacks by moving your little hearth, also you can spare enemies by flirting or just talking a bit with them. Everything that you do in Undertale feels important on the story, with amazing characters, amazing 4th wall breaking, amazing jokes and humor and lots of endings depending on the way you act through the game. 10/10 Is a must have if you like this kind of games.
Best ps4 game for 2017? Are you freaking kidding me? Totally lost my faith in game reviews. Games like these should be hyped by users, not critics. I still can't believe my eyes ((

this game is cool and I like it a lot. it has some cool elements in it that remind me of the old days of rpg's. even though this game is almost 2 years old it still holds up as one of the best games of that year

I was so disappointed by the PS4 port that I won't say much. I know it's made in RPG Maker and runs in 20fps. That's fine. But why did you have to compress the audio so it sounds like **** The music is perhaps the best element in this game and it's ruined by unnecessary lossy compression (It sounds great on PC). PS4 Port sucks, if you really want it, get it on PC instead.
I've never loved such games, But this game is just great! Nice graphics and an amazing story! Bosses lead to horror! A lot of very interesting characters! I recommend to play!

Mediocre. Game makes you feel too bad about killing ONE thing even if it is an accident. Pacifist cant even be achieved without doing unnecessary tasks just to pad out game play. Story could have been more. At points it is gimmicky. %/!)
THE most innovative RPG of this decade. It's so simple, but so deep, I want to scream. Characters, music, plot - all on the highest level. Sony players now сan also feel the magic of friendship

Undertale is a really cute and quirky game. It's one of those games that can really help to put you in a good mood if you're feeling down because it's (at times quite bizarre) humor. The battle system is super unique and the ability to not kill a single enemy allows for a much different strategy from most games. I can understand how it wouldn't be a game for everyone because if you don't appreciate its quirkiness a lot of the game's humor will be lost on you. It is a little short but it has good replay value and for a cost of $15 dollars you can't expect a game that's the length of Skyrim and at that price you gotta check it out at the very least because it's a truly unique gaming experience!
Perfect, a game with a great music, a nice story and i love the "battle minigames". San's boss battle is very complicated if you selected genocide route and the characters are very charismatic

I was expecting this release because i didn't play it on pc. I can say that for me this game was a big disappointment, yes the music is good, and the combat is sometimes fun, but the game was extremely boring and annoying, also, i was expecting an incredible story, but no. At least, the are some good characters, but only that.

Undertale is a fantastic RPG with a beautiful story. At its core it is a simple exploration game with optional combat encounters. It has such an amazing personality and the humor is very unique. It parodies typical game tropes while incorporating its own perspective.

I do not know how awful game like this is so popular. The whole time I played this thing, the only point I found positive was the soundtrack, but the rest is so bland. The combat system is crap and weird. The characters are annoying and their jokes make me facepalm because they are so stupid!

In single word - boring. Tried it on PC, tried several times, but it is just boring. It is a joke that it pretends to be #1 game of PS4. There should be another score for such games - in bananas or apples.

Okay...I'm just surprised to see this game on ps4 because, in all honesty, this game is just overhyped to extreme levels and really, the only appeal of this game is the fan service for the creator and that's it: the characters have personalities of a cardboard and killing someone by mistake is just a long streak of guilt trip, which is the cheapest and most heartless way to make someone feel bad. The writing is okay but it's not really the best: it's too cheesy and gets boring after a while, which is what people praise the most but I've seen better.
stop being cranks and enjoy the game.

Undertale is one of those over-rated Indie games like Five Nights At Freddy’s. The game is very bland and was made with RPG Maker! Undertale has only story going for it and offers no gameplay whatsoever.
While I never really liked Undertlae, porting it on PS4 made it even worse because of a very uncomfortable controls. I don't think that games of that kind play well on home consoles.

Random Encounters. If you don't like random encounters you will hate this game. I don't like random encounters....I hate random encounters. I hate repetitive, never ending random encounters. So I find this game unplayable, because I'm always doing random encounters.

Very impressive for only one person to have made it, I guess?  The soundtrack is definitely catchy.  But the gameplay is just boring as hell.  I don't get it.  I've played games my entire life and I don't understand the appeal of this.  Multiple endings aren't enough to interest me.  The gameplay has to be fun enough to warrant those multiple playthroughs, and it's not.  It's like a RPG that doesn't want to be a RPG; it tries so hard to go against standard gaming conventions that it isn't really...anything. And the puzzles are freaking terrible.  What is so fun about this?
Я не понял игру. Да, куча мемов, куча шуточек и т.д. но ничего, кроме этого нет. Кто-то пишет о филасафии, но я её не нашёл. Возможно, я просто пока не готов к игре.
I'm giving this game a 10/10 because without it we wouldn't have all those dank undertale cringe compilations since the fanbase would never exist.
What can I say about Undertale that already hasn't been said... so I'll just mention difference of the PS4 version...
A surprisingly heartfelt game with a quirky sense of humour. It's pretty much a masterclass in storytelling; drip feeding bits here and there until it all comes together in the conclusion.

Don't go into Undertale for its game play. its bullet hell play style is refreshing, and the game makes a good effort to keep things new, but it gets boring nonetheless. Go into Undertale for its story. So thought provoking and dark, I found myself enjoying the characters almost as much as the - better than any other single video game - music. But it is a little too dark, the fun loving and child like aesthetic deceive you into this rather creepy game. I found myself unwilling to begin playing, but as I did, it didn't seem that bad. That's because it depends on how you play the game, it encourages you to not kill anything, so unassuming old me did exactly what Toriel instructed me to do. I played the game again after experiencing the true lab, only to find out what happens when you actively kill everything. It kept me up at night. you can call me a woos but I wasn't going anywhere near that game, I don't do horror usually, so it was the same kind of shock I would get reading a creepy pasta. There are some very eerie undertones to Undertale, so keep that in mind when you, or your five year old decide to give it a go

Undertale is an amazing game for anyone. It may not look appealing at first glance, but this game holds so much more beneath it's surface. It's a heartfelt adventure that messes with you're emotions and head. The soundtrack is also fantastic. If you're going to play, to get the best experience I suggest you go in completely blind to any kind of spoilers. You will be amazed.
really this is a good game it is now on ps4 and now the nintendo switch and its not my favorite game

Undertale is a lighthearted RPG about many different things. You play as a child that fell inside a mountain full of monsters that vary from being friendly and being an enemy. I suggest going into this game as unbiased you can be. Some parts of the fan base of this game can be annoying at times (obviously not all of them just the very vocal fans of this game). I highly recommend this game to anyone that wants to play a fun RPG.

On September 15 2015 the hit indie sensation “Undertale” was released by Toby Fox onto the PC platform “Steam” where it quickly grew in popularity and fandom. However by April 2016 the game seemed to have died out in popularity. Today people will tell you the game is complete garbage. But how good was the game? To answer I played through the game 3 times (one for each route) to see just how good or bad this game really is.

title: Unearthing Mars
summary: Carrier-class spacecraft Sentra has arrived in Mars orbit, tasked to retrieve remnants of the missing explorer satellite Phobos. What they will uncover instead are the possible vestiges of an ancient civilization.
reviews: I'd say Unearthing Mars is well worth a couple of hours away from the real world. It's rough around the edges, but there are some great ideas at play and an enjoyable adventure to be had.
Our advice is to buy Unearthing Mars only in case of a big discount, or if you want to try your hand in a space adventure that is short, simple and immediate.

Unearthing Mars is a difficult game to write about simply because it comes and goes without ever giving you much to go on. By the time the credits roll you’ll already find yourself forgetting what actually happened. Maybe there is life to find on Mars, but you won’t find any here.

Unearthing Mars begins as a serious expedition to Mars only to transform into a laughably bad science fiction space opera about angry aliens and partying pig dog beasts. It won’t leave you with anything to remember it by, except for how laughably bad it is. The experience of Unearthing Mars is a lot like being EPCOT Center’s Spaceship Earth while riding high on bad weed.
Unearthing Mars takes you on a journey from your living room to the red planet in 10 short levels. Push a few buttons, twiddle some knobs and that’s about all there is to this title.
Finally a game does not take less than 30 minutes to complete, is not just a point and click and even uses move controllers! To bad that the rest of the game is very uninteresting.

unearthing mars is your greatest adventure of all time specially for kids over 12 years of age. This is wonderland mystery and suspend waiting for discovery. it give you kids to control big four by four car now how cool is that. You can replay all the chapter as many time as you wish and the fun is always there along with you. Travel to many exotics place with spooky environment and fun animal to see. So put on your armour  of bravery and exploration Einstein  to boldly go where no kids has ever gone before.

title: Unepic
summary: Unepic is a combination of platforming and role playing games. There are many hilarious references throughout the game. The game takes place in Harnakon, a huge medieval castle.
reviews: Unepic is one of the best Spanish games of recent years. It's not perfect, absolutely not, but the sense of humour and its RPG gameplay will catch you.

UnEpic is a big Metroidvania game which offers tons of weapons, enemies and rooms. It easily entertains you for 15 hours, but meanwhile the jokes can become an overkill. Still, the game is absolutely worth your time and money.
UnEpic makes a mockery of all the material that the author knows and loves deeply, if it is true that almost single-handedly he put together a huge and well structured game.

Unepic is not a perfect game by any means. Its tongue-in-cheek premise isn't everybody's cup of tea, and it doesn't particularly break any new ground. Instead what we get is a competent, if slightly linear, Metroidvania-style RPG that knows how to pace itself to keep the player engaged.

UnEpic is a title full of humour, detailed narration, superb voice casting and addictive gameplay. Overall, UnEpic really did keep my attention, which is something I’ve failed to find in relation to indie titles. I wanted to keep on playing which is always a great feeling for any enthusiastic gamer. Despite a few cons in terms in visuals and overall features, it is definitely forgiven and recognition is well deserved for the developer behind UnEpic.

Unepic is an enjoyable retro style action RPG.  It has not gotten the attention or acclaim of some more recent retro style 2D platformers such as Axiom Verge or Shovel Knight, but fans of that style of gameplay should give this one a look.

In the end, whether or not you enjoy Unepic will depend on whether or not you enjoy reference humour, and if your enjoyment of the exploration outweighs your frustration with the mediocre combat. Depending on which platform you’re buying it, the game costs anywhere between $9 and $15, so if Unepic sounds like something you’d be interested in, you may want to give it a try. Otherwise, this is one quest you’re better off skipping.

In the end, Unepic would probably be a better adventure game. This twenty hour or so unabashedly old school RPG is frequently broken up by conversations between characters and these interactions are amusing enough to make the often finicky platforming and combat sections worth persevering with.
It just feels like it was made by children. And not in a cute way. [June 2016, p.94]
A very beautiful platform Rpg game.This game reminds me  the Castlevania for ps1 .

This game has all the rpg elements one could hope for. Game mechanics might not be quite at par with other side scroller Metroidvania games but the loot, abilities, and cheesy storyline make up for it.

title: Unmechanical: Extended Edition
summary: Explore the non-linear levels at your own pace, many of which will require some out-of-the-box thinking and the process of trying to find the solution is just as important as progressing the story.
reviews: Unmechanical: Extended won't blow too many people away, but I don't think anyone can doubt its heart is in the right place.
While it may be on the short side, I still highly recommend picking up Unmechanical Extended. Like me, you may have a really fun time with it.
Unmechanical Extending offers gamers a puzzle game with a story told though its setting, more thought provoking than games with hours of pre-recorded dialogue.
My only request for any future instalments that may be planned would be for somebody to please turn on the frickin’ lights.
As a result, if you're up for a puzzle game – but are normally turned off by more complex entries in the genre – then this is well worth beaming into your collection.

Unmechanical: Extended Edition is a mostly rewarding and wonderfully atmospheric puzzler with only a few significant flaws. A few of the puzzles just seem poorly designed, which clash with the great puzzles that thankfully populate most of the game.
An enjoyable and attractive, if overly-familiar physics based puzzler, Unmechanical Extended could be just the ticket for puzzler aficionados looking for a game to burn the hours away.
Unmechanical Extended is a fun game, but the Extended version offers nothing new. Graphically it's a unique game and the gameplay is great, but there is no real challenge. Still it is worth buying.
A good puzzle and adventure game that doesn't bring anything new, but it's plain fun.
A rather lovely reminder of how satisfying a good old fashioned puzzle game can be without squeezing your brain dry of every drop of spurious logic. [Apr 2015, p.87]
Unmechanical Extended is a good puzzle game with a charming atmosphere.

Unmechanical: Extended is a cute little experience. The stories are told in a way that takes at least a little bit of effort on the player's part. For those willing to put that effort in, and the effort to get through the puzzle rooms, escaping from the tiny robot gulag is a worthy way to spend a day.

Unmechanical: Extended is a beautiful game. The graphics and landscapes are simply stunning and the character has real heart, despite being a little helpless. It's a pity that it leaves the door open to questions about the quality of puzzles, however.
Unmechanical: Extended offers interesting graphics and enjoyable puzzles. There's just too little to differentiate it from dozens of other independents games already on sale.

A real gem of a title, Unmechanical has great 60fps graphics, a great soundtrack, a unique atmosphere and a good collection of puzzles to work your way through.  Amazed there are no other user reviews of this yet, you're missing out.
Intriguing puzzle game in 2.5D. It's not too challenging once you find out all the mechanics present in the game and how to use them to your advantage, and the game isn't too long either.

A slow paced 2d puzzle/platformer, with the focus very much on the puzzle solving, Unmechanical is decent enough (especially as it is currently free on PS+) but if you’ve ever played this type of game before you’ll find no new ideas whatsoever and, as is always the case, some of the later puzzles are just too obscure. It is also all over in little more than an hour with no incentive to play through it more than once.

As a big fan of Rochard, which it I heard it compared to, I thought I would like this but this game just doesn't have the same charm as Rochard. Rochard had an interesting character versus Unmechanical that just has a voiceless blob going through and environment solving puzzles. Not bad but puzzle games need more to hold my interest these days.

A great way to waste a few hours, but not quite offering enough to make it a truly great puzzle platformer. The puzzles are all rather simple, and the game is extremely short, even with the extended edition. Doesn't do anything that other game haven't already done better.

Fun short puzzle game. I actually like these games short, as they usually get too frustrated if they are long, short and sweet is the best. The game is a standard puzzle game with an interesting story.

Anything new, but I really liked the setting and atmosphere. It's some buggy, but it's worth to play once it is short. Not for puzzles, but they also are simple and clever. I found some similarities with Journey: simplicity, implication in the story. Good short game, and its good because its short.

title: Uno
summary: Uno makes its return to consoles and PC with an assortment of exciting features such as added video chat support and an all new theme system which adds more fun to enjoy your Uno game!
reviews: Uno makes for a good alternative to the type of fare typically seen on a console. Despite its simple rules, it remains fun thanks to the decent AI and the good-sized online community. It may not be as cheap as the Xbox 360 release was, but if you're looking for a fun card game on the PS4, you can't go wrong with Uno.
I was really pleased with this new offering of Uno. It’s one of those games that I will forever be opening up for a few quick matches
Ultimately, if you enjoy Uno then you’ll probably enjoy this version of it.
A never-ending success, Uno arrives on current gen console with a funny Ubisoft style twist... and more to come.
The popular board game comes again with a lots of fun, entertainment and its unique style. If you enjoyed playing it with your friends, you will really like this videogame version.

Ubisoft Chengdu’s UNO does exactly what it sets out to do, it’s a polished (although not perfect) digital version of the beloved card game. The lack of decks is disappointing, but it definitely delivers the same brand of fun that gamers had 10 years ago on Xbox 360.

As with many classic board and card games, Uno isn’t perfect. It’s driven by luck, games tend to go overlong, and Ubisoft’s no-frills approach is workable, but workmanlike. Despite that, I do really enjoy the core game of Uno in short bursts, and for people who regularly play online with family and friends (and can thus do away with the occasionally irritating random players), this is a great, low-cost way to spend a Saturday evening together when separated by distance.
It's Uno. On PlayStation 4. Nothing more, nothing less. What you do with that information, is entirely up to you.
The PS4 version of Uno is an average offering that doesn’t take advantage of the fact that it’s a digital game.
Uno is a great card game, however this version fails to understand the social aspects of card games. It shines if you have friends to play it with, otherwise it's a bit of a bore.
There are many options missing. The game go back to the main menu after each round. there is not option to stay in the room to play again with the same people.
If you want a basic game of Uno, then this is a solid purchase. As others have said, it does lack a few features and the multiplayer aspect of it is a bit cumbersome.

I think Uno is a great addition to consoles of any generation. Yes,  the multi-play could use some sharpening and simplification overall.  However,  it is still a fun game to play and has some good variations in the types of games which can be played.  If a person is looking to kill some time and play a classic fun card game on the console,  Uno is the game to definitely buy.  One con I will mention though is the pricing.  $14.99 is a bit steep for a simple card game but not a deal breaker.

While not the best multiplayer experience (see various other reviews for details) this is still an enjoyable single-player experience. The game won't break the bank and can easily amuse for a few hours. The variety of basic content is small and the DLC card packs actually contain new features. However given that it costs less than £5/$7 this is a small issue.

title: Unravel
summary: Yarny's mission is to mend broken bonds and the yarn represents the love and connection between people. The player will use Yarny's thread to do things such as swinging across gaps or rappelling down trees. Te game will also challenge gamers to use the thread in clever and creative ways. [Electronic Arts]
reviews: I spent a very long time trying to come up with a reason to mark Unravel down as a game but I just… can’t! Really, I can’t think of one negative thing to say about it. From the visuals to the audio, the smooth and responsive gameplay (and lack of glitches) to the touching story/message; there is nothing wrong with this game. Honestly, if you even slightly enjoy puzzle or platformer games, even slightly, buy Unravel. Do it.
It’s a beautiful game about human emotions and memories, and while I hope there’s never a sequel, I cannot wait to see what this team comes up with next.

Clocking in at a little under 6 hours, there was no part of Unravel that I found wanting. Great visuals, excellent mechanics, and a satisfyingly sweet, personal narrative background make this a complete no-brainer in my book. I adore this game, and if you have any kind of a heart beating inside of you, I have no doubt that you will too.

The atmosphere is so compelling that I couldn’t help but feel like a piece of my own story was wrapped up in the game with the rest of the photo album. It’s rare but a special thing when a game manages to impart a story that touches strings deep in the heart, and Unravel manages to meet and exceed this feat. Get ready to have all the feels.

I walked away from Unravel thinking not about those moments of frustration, plentiful as they are. All I could think about - and still keep thinking about - is the beautiful adventure I’d been on with Yarny, all culminating in one of the most captivating, lovely, heartwarming endings I’ve seen.Truly, Unravel is a special game.
It's very sad to score with numbers a game made of hearth. Sorry about that, Unravel. You're more than a videogame, you're the soul of your creators.

Unravel is not only an eye candy, it fulfills its objectives as a good videogame with interesting platforming challenges based on the unraveled character and its yarn. With an outstanding presentation, beautiful landscapes, sensitive story and reflexive ambients, it's a pleasure that many people should enjoy.
Yarny heads a fantastic 2D platformer that suffers from one or two issues, but ultimately becomes one of the more enjoyable experiences in recent memory.
A moving puzzle platformer bolstered by strong level design, a creative mechanic, and an unbelievably endearing main character

What does matter is that in Unravel Coldwood has succeeded in creating a beautiful, poignant, and compelling game interested in going beyond mere entertainment. It wants to make us think about the what and why of everything that happens.

Unravel is a story about a family you don’t know and memories you don’t have. Its journey is watching and becoming the force piecing them together, a force that takes shape in a small, humble character named Yarny.
Unravel is a gorgeous, tender, heartwarming experience. Endearing to the last thanks to a well-designed world and achingly sweet protagonist.

It feels like the game equivalent to your favorite art house movie, where it speaks a message that is both universal, and yet completely personal to you. Even beyond the artistic, the game functions well on a technical level, delivering both great graphics and fantastic music, while also hitting on some great gameplay. Trial and error deaths get in the way, and some puzzles might frustrate, but overall Unravel is a triumphant experience from start to finish.

It’s an experience that was quite intense for this particular reviewer. It is a wondrously constructed game born of love and culminating as an incredibly, beautifully bittersweet, emotional adventure. Filled with heart from its opening to the cessation of the credits, it will wow you, make you smile and make you cry. Gamer or not, you need to play Unravel.
Unravel’s appeal goes far beyond pretty levels. Beautiful, poignant and with an iron grip on your heart, Yarny manages to effortlessly deliver a wonderful platformer and a bittersweet message.
A wonderful platform adventure set in the beautiful Swedish wilderness. Not many games come close in graphical prowess.
A wonder to play, a joy to experience, a feast for the senses and a heartfelt story told by a team of passionate developers.

Like the biggest Pixar's productions, Unravel delivers on very different levels. On one hand, it's a 2D platformer-puzzler that is very well-designed and, on the other hand, offers a poetic message about life, friendship and death. All wrapped in its own style, with a lovely main character made of wool and a fantastic world to explore and interact with, with great visuals and soundtrack. It's sold as an indie game, but at some points it looks more like a triple A game. If you loved Journey and other art-games, you should go for it.

Unravel is a unique piece of art in a gaming world filled with first-person shooters and epic AAA titles. It’s not perfect, but it does a great job challenging one’s brain, while delivering some visually stunning scenery to make you forget you’re working hard to progress and push through.

It is really hard not to fall in love with Unravel. The atmospheric, beautiful world is the perfect setting for an emotional story. There are a few hiccups when it comes to gameplay, but thanks to the quality of the adventure that is hardly noticeable.

Unravel isn't perfect or particularly original, but there's so much love and care put into it that it becomes something unique and special. One of those games that you'll enjoy if you need a break from Triple A and blockbusters.
Unravel is a fleeting yet enjoyable experience, with great gameplay and production design. Experienced players may find it too easy, but it's a gorgeous blend of story and gameplay for everyone else.

It might be tempting to write off Unravel as another indie-made platformer, but you’d be denying yourself a surprisingly deep puzzler with an unmeasurable amount of charm. There might not be much replay value, but you’ll be glad you took the time to see it to the end.

As a puzzler it has charm due to Yarny’s engaging skills, but as a platforming experience it’s less remarkable. But to judge it solely on these mechanical aspects would be to overlook its greater achievement: the way it provokes subtle and complex emotions through the use of nature and nostalgia. It all makes for a sincere, warm-hearted, and extremely likeable adventure.
Unravel is a gorgeous tribute to the little things in live. A touching, soft story that’s rarely seen in games.

Unravel's audiovisual beauty is only paralleled by the sympathy Yarny inspires, with all its cuteness and immortality. Although Coldwood Interactive has made some gameplay mistakes that weigh down the experience quite a bit, you can't ignore all the effort they put in the game, that plays with nostalgia like few other games have achieved.
A platform-puzzler with real heart, Unravel makes up for mechanical shortcomings with a world as palpable as it is pretty. It's no classic, but it's a memorable journey all the same. [Apr 2016, p.90]
Unravel is a beautiful, serene platformer with neat idea. [March 2016]

An ode to joy. Unravel is a relaxing game that strikes a chord with many of its players. It is a calm, joyous adventure with not so complex puzzles nor gameplay, yet adorable little voyage you'll gladly take.

Unravel is a bit of a slow starter, but as the adventure unfolds it’s easy to get totally lost in the beautiful scenery and the stunning graphics. It’s a game that's going to make you feel warm and joyful, and for that we can overlook some of the lesser parts, like the puzzle design.

It’s true that there is a lot of room for improvement, especially on the puzzle department. Nevertheless, Coldwood Interactive made a major comeback with Unravel, a game which has some of the finest visuals we‘ve seen and an outright adorable main character which is a joy to handle.
As cute as it is touching, and as unique as it is enjoyable, Unravel is a title very much worth experiencing.

While Unravel might not be the deepest experience or present the most complex puzzles to solve, the impossibly beautiful presentation is overwhelming and Yarny is a character that's easy to love. This small-scale journey of the mind and heart had no trouble keeping me engaged until the last memory was found, and I look forward to what this developer does next, even if yarn isn't involved.
This isn't a stitched-together game in danger of falling apart, but a well-constructed and surprisingly emotional platformer.
It's not the most difficult platformer ever made, but Unravel manages to deliver a truly sweet, gentle and tender experience. It's a delicate, red ball of yarn that will twine around your heart.

Unravel is certainly one of the most charming games in recent years, one filled with intimate details from the author's life - perhaps a bit too often. It does not change the fact that - if we accept such concept - we're in for a treat.
Yarny’s journey might have its ups and downs, but it’s brief and beautiful. It is a mostly wordless message of love.
Unravel is pure charm from start to finish. It's not going to redefine the platformer genre, but it's a wonderfully atmospheric and enjoyable title with solid gameplay and delightful visuals.

The team wanted to make it more than just a cute face and pretty graphics. Even if puzzles can seem obtuse, seldom do they ever feel impossible. The few faults in Unravel can be excused, because it’s so well executed. With the emotions it stirs and the warmth it makes you feel, it’s obvious that a lot of heart was poured into this game.
Unravel is like a colored Limbo. It's a touching and creative trip, even if it lacks a bit of depth and is sometimes repetitive.
Unravel is a solid (if flawed) puzzle platformer wrapped up in beautiful visuals and emotional moments. It's like a Christmas sweater. It's not perfect, but you're compelled to love it just the same.

A beautiful first try, that deserves to be played. It ain’t perfect, due to some design problems in the second half of the game, but it’s also a splendid title, whose locations and protagonist will stay in your heart for a while.

Unravel is a remarkable achievement on the artistic side, with some evocative nordic landscapes and an effective protagonist. But the dualism between his platform and puzzle mechanics are not totally convincing, and the level design is a bit flat.

Unravel is a delicate game, cloaked in an overall positive morale. The gameplay is as light as the graphics and the narration, and that will surely disappoint those who will look for a deeper platforming experience, but the atmosphere is still unique, and sound.

Unravel never entirely shakes that aura of niceness over its five hours or so. It is both its strength and weakness. The background tale of Yarny searching through a family’s memories is a bit mawkish, but the little fella’s determination to trek through the challenges Coldwood chucks at him is adorable and endearing.
With smart gameplay, gorgeous graphics, and a brilliant story to tell, it looks as though Unravel could be ColdWood’s first breakout hit and a deserving one at that.
Simple in its mechanics but very refined, Unravel is a charming adventure that will probably make you remember some distant memory with a smile.
Its puzzles can be a little woolly, but Unravel has endless spools of charm. [March 2016, p.70]

Unravel isn’t a bad game on any level but it can be frustrating and the margin of error is not very forgiving for some of the puzzles. Nonetheless, it does have its moments of glory which did keep me interested and motivated to finish the game.

With just a dozen levels, Unravel's brief six-hour runtime still proves too long for the basic puzzle mechanics. However, the satisfying platforming, thoughtful story, and adorable protagonist make it a worthwhile journey. I grew tired of repeating the same puzzle solutions, but seeing Unravel through to the end was still a treat.

The game shines through its stunning visuals, heartfelt soundtrack and unique platforming elements creating a truly unforgettable experience. Unfortunately, gameplay does lack substance, as it can be completed in just six hours and lacks any real replay value.
We were expecting one of the best games indies can make but the truth is Unravel is just a good game. Good, but very far from something like LIMBO or the recent Ori and the Blind Forest.

The game constantly hints at greater things, but never quite reaches those heights. In the end, instead of feeling moved, we felt content. A wonderfully charming game with gorgeous, varied stages and crafty puzzles, but we wish it left more of a lasting mark.

From the moment that little ball of red yarn tumbled down the old woman’s steps to the last bit of yarn that I strung from place to place in the old woman’s memories, I enjoyed almost every step, swing, and catapult. The emotive little Yarny had me feeling for him as I traversed the dangerous terrain with his ever unraveling figure. Though the gameplay falls victim to ebbs and flows of being too frustrating at times and too easy at others, it was still an overall enjoyable experience.
Like its enigmatic protagonist, Unravel is never anything less than charming, even during moments when it doesn't quite hold together. [April 2016, p.108]

When it all comes together – and it often does – Unravel is an adorable game with a charming soundtrack and some gorgeous background environments. There’s still a sense of satisfaction each time you solve a puzzle and Yarny’s animations are enough to warm your heart. It’s just a shame that the game’s myriad frustrating moments ensure this warm heart is accompanied by heat under the collar.
Endearing, gorgeous platformer that tugs on the heartstrings early, but ultimately winds up feeling mechanically threadbare. [April 2016, p77]
It's gorgeous, it truly is, but Unravel falls short of being the emotionally engaging game we were expecting. It's still fun, but feels much hollower than it clearly intended to be. [Issue#267, p.70]

It’s charming and easy to fall in love with - dependant on your familiarity with storytelling in games away from the blockbuster excesses. However, picking it up expecting deep gameplay and equally involved experiences would be potentially too hasty.

Even though I enjoyed Unravel I wish there was more of it. Strip away the beautiful wrapping and heartwarming story, and you're left with a fairly simple game with not too difficult puzzles that won't last you more than three or four hours. Thankfully, it's that simplicity that makes it work.
This generation has seen a glut of puzzle platformers grace the PlayStation 4, but fortunately for those interested, Unravel is absolutely one that deserves attention.
Unravel might look like LittleBigPlanet, but in practice it’s the kinder, gentler Limbo.
An astoundingly beautiful puzzle platformer, that’s a little too frustrating in practice but far from the twee family game some may mistake it for.

Unravel's strengths lie more in its heart-warming story than offering compelling gameplay. Even though there are some thought-provoking puzzles, they’re few and far between. There’s no doubt Yarny is quite the adorable little mascot who has good intentions, but a video game can’t succeed on good intentions alone.
Assessed purely on gameplay, it’s everything I tend to fear about indie projects; Beautiful, heartfelt, but like Yarny himself, not robust enough.
When Unravel did not annoy me with its poor level design and shortcomings related to gameplay mechanics, it was really enjoyable. [03/2016, p.38]
Unravel is a beautiful puzzle platform game that quite vividly speaks to your emotions. The downside however, is that the game itself is simply not a lot of fun to play.
Unravel puts all its cards on being cute and charming while having repetitive, lackluster gameplay. If you're looking for a very casual cute game, you might forgive its shortcomings

Over the course of my seven hours with the game, it was an enjoyable, simple and easy experience. Unravel doesn't do anything special with its gameplay or narrative, though it does have a magnificent soundtrack and stunning visuals. If you're a person who is a hardcore platforming fan, you will most likely be very underwhelmed with Unravel, but if you're looking for a fun, easy and light experience, then maybe this game is for you.

Despite all of its cutesy posturing and promises, Unravel is still looking to fill some kind of void. And I’m not sure if that void is its shortcomings as a mood board, as a videogame, or a cloying digestible basket of “feels” for EA.
Unravel can deliver some picturesque desktop wallpaper, but when in motion, this 2D platformer becomes a frustrating puzzler that expects you to know more than you've been taught.
When the end titles start rolling, you’ll look back at your journey in disbelief, saying “And this is it? So, those were the puzzles?! Wait, what about the story?”

Cloying adorability is Unravel‘s saving grace. Propped up on a crutch constructed from mawkish sentimentality, it gets away with a fair few missteps and manages to claw together a smattering of memorable moments. This pretty shell, however, is undeniably a shell, and no amount of pretty little animations can make up for a total drought of engaging game design.

What a great game and i preordered it long time ago. This is my first digital game that I ever preordered and I made the right decision. It doesn't look like a indie game with absolutely high quality and polish. There are a lot of great looking indie games but this game looks like a AAA title.
I have completed the story on PS4.

You have to play this game at least once. Reminds me of Little Big Planet and Limbo, with a soundtrack inspired by Journey. Though it borrows from those amazing games, it throws in new ways of solving puzzles with yarn limitations. It's clever, cute, very nice to look at, and enjoyable to play. Well worth the 20 bucks!

Un juego precioso, hecho con mimo y cariño y con un mensaje muy importante sobre la vida muy emcionante.... Si bien es verdad que no innova en nada, el objetivo no era ese, el objetivo era contar una historia, hacerla bella y hacer sentir al jugador sensaciones reales, cosa que han conseguido con creces. La banda sonora es sencillamente excepcional y la direccion de arte es de lo mas bonito que he visto en mucho tiempo en un videojuego. Es puro arte, una belleza de juego.

What a great game.  It's absolutely beautiful, in terms of graphics, animation, sound, foley, music and especially plot.  I will admit that the gameplay is a little simple, but really, it's so so so so beautifully put together that I can't give it less than a 10.
Similar to Child of Light and Limbo.
I tried to give this game a chance but it just kind of got tedious to me after a while. Which is such a shame because it has great graphics. Not much to say other than that.

An adorable adventure that'll bring you to the brink of tears both happy and sad. It's clear there's a lot of love and soul placed in the game which is incredibly ironic when EA is the one publishing it. It has rather simple gameplay you solve physic based puzzles with your physic defying yarn with the subtle message of life being like yarn. However the game is more enjoyable in short bursts as some complicated puzzles will leave you exhausted while some will bore you with how simple they are. Story is you are Yarny and it's up to you to explore the world and find memories (both good and bad) to place in your scrap book, first starting from the happy worry free child hood to the inevitable horror of reality, which is emphasized more with your size as small trivial things become huge obstacles to think around. One way or another you're going to have a warm feeling in your heart when playing the game (more so if you made a Yarny doll!).

I made this account solely to review this game. I played it with my girlfriend as we fancied playing a puzzle game. Unravel had me in tears, it is an absolute work of art! The OST is stunning, graphically it is superb, the game play is fun and I loved the world so much that I had to play through it again to find every secret. Who would have thought that a simple metaphor could produce such a beautiful game. This is a game that everybody should play from start to finish before they die

Unravel looks amazing, better than in the tech demo, have a cute character that tries to help and old lady to recover her memories, you will face puzzles and a great history, OST gives the touch of an indie artistic game, the problem maybe is that some puzzles are repetitive and also the length of the game, more less 7 hours but is a low price tittle, definitively a great choice for this year and a serious candidate for Indie of the Year

If Indiana Jones were four inches tall, made of red yarn and in search of a bunch of family pictures and fibrous pendants instead of relics he would be the protagonist of Coldwood Interactive’s newest game. Unravel is an offering that can be put into the same general category as gems like Journey, Broken Age and Entwined.

Unravel appears to have a lot to offer.  It is a side-scrolling puzzle/platformer very much in the style of the ever popular Limbo.  However, where as Limbo was a very dark and gloomy game Unravel is both vibrant and colorful.  This is a really pretty game that takes place across several realistic looking environments.  You traverse these different areas as Yarny, a little red yarn doll.  On your journey you will revisit memories of the life of older lady that sewed you together.  Its quite an adventure that tries to carve its own unique path from other similar games.
This is a little marvel. I absolutely love how cute this game is. Yet it is challenging. Feels very polished and does what it sets out do to. I'd love to see a follow-up.

This game looks and sounds great. The environments are so beautiful, they really can suck you in and make you remember times in your own life that were pivotal or give you that feeling of nostalgia.  However, no matter how great a game looks, it still needs to be fun. Unravel has moments of fun gaming, but almost all of the puzzles are too easy to figure out. The hardest thing about the game is the controls, which are mostly fine, but that can cause frustration during an otherwise simple task in the game. Fun, but definitely not one of the all-time greats of platforming or puzzling.

this game is so beautiful and fun to play. i am enjoying it.  Yarn look cute. i hope i can get platinum trophy on this game if i can.. 19.99 is not bad price to buy and enjoy it. i hope haters better not vote bad score on this game

Let me start off by saying this is the best $20 I have ever spent. I am not finished with the game yet, but none the less it is still captivating and beautiful. The level of detail and art design is something to be desired even by AAA standards. The music couples with the scenery in a serene way. The narrative behind this truly calls back to a simpler time. From a gameplay standpoint, I have no issue with it. When there was a puzzle that took a while to solve, it brought a big smile when I figured out what to do. I can't remember the last game that made me smile this much. The developers put such passion into this game, and it shows. It may not be for everybody, but I would recommend it!
looks like a jumpnrun but is actually more of a puzzle game, if youre ok with that go for it. not my cup of tea but very well crafted and reasonably prized

I could say a lot about this warmhearted, magical, pure product of love. But I won't. This is another indie masterpiece that has to be played and experienced. As a game, it's a solid and fun puzzle-solving platformer; but it is way more than that. I had a wonderful time with "Unravel", which gave me in 7h/8h so much more than most of the games I've played recently have given me.
My god. This is not just a game, it's pure art.

Unravel easily achieves everything it sets out to do - it is a moving, beautifully crafted game that features both perfect pacing and the right amount of content for its price point (around 5-6 hours). Some media offered lower review scores primarily because they felt solutions to puzzles were not somehow inherently obvious, or that there was too much trial-and-error, so I unfortunately approached the game with some caution. This was not my experience, however, and while I did get stuck at a few sections, it never felt cheap or tricky, and a few minutes of thinking or a few good, agile swings always had me on my way - exactly what a game should expect from the player. As someone who purchases games weekly, I wouldn't easily offer a perfect 10 for a game, but Coldwood deserves all the praise and support it has earned with Unravel. Comparisons to games like Journey are inevitable, in part because it pays obvious homage to the title in its later stages, but its message and experience hold the same impact as these other "indie" greats, and this is an easy purchase for anyone looking to feel all the feels as they take Yarny out to explore a world in which it is all too easy to come undone.

This is the first 10 I put on a review ever, and this is a SOLID 10. I absolutely loved the originalty of the game, the poetry, beauty of the graphics, and the game play. It's a wonderful experience and it brings some fresh air in the video game industry.

The best way to experience this majesty of a game is to play it yourself... read closely at the negative and mixed reviews. Send them to the creator and maybe the creator will give us an Unravel 2 with a twist. Other than that...this is my GAME OF THE YEAR FOR 2016! This game helped washed the taste out of my mouth on a plethora of broken games, Rise of the Tomb Raider game breaking bugs, fighting games (Street Fighter V, MKX XL and KI season 3) and etc. THANK YOU TO THOSE APART OF UNRAVEL!!!
Incredible. Amazing. Fun. Melancholic. Deep. Beautiful. Mysterious. Easy. Hardcore. Smart. Huge. Surprising. Deep. Touching.

Unravel is a game that tells a beautiful story, more than decent graphics, original gameplay similar to that of Limbo and many other things. Without doubt one of the best games that EA has given us in a long time.
This game shows that good visuals and physics can mask a game's bad level design and poorly made puzzles that can be often exploited without using the elements intended for use by the developer.

Un juego precioso que derrocha amor y esfuerzo por parte de los creadores, no es un juego de plataformas que te pida una gran habilidad para saltar, correr y derrotar enemigos; es un juego para el disfrute de los sentidos, relajarte y reflexionar sobre la vida
This game starts out great - the same part of the game is shown in the demo, which clearly shows that the devs are aware that this is their strong part of the game.

Beautiful looking game, with some puzzles to challenge you. Overall though, I wasnt too impressed. I couldnt connect with yarny and the story. I didnt feel invested in going through the stages to complete whatever story this game has. In the end, i lost interest completely. As for game play, pretty straight forward, you have to reach the end of the mission using a few tricks you learn at the beginning (swinging, creating small bridges, grappling up to places, and interacting a little with the environment). Visually lovely, but gameplay is not fun. Even as a platformer, yarny does not feel as fluid as he should.

The game is beautiful but not a good puzzle platformer.  No really new elements are introduced to increase complexity of puzzles.  The puzzles are sparse (mostly you just run right), and simple (mostly involve tying a rope bridge off or tying two things together).  Very boring.

Unravel is an absolutely charming little 2d puzzle platformer in which the player must guide a character made of wool (he’s called Yarny) through a series of different environments. As you make your way through each level your wool gradually unravels behind you, hence the games title, and this wool can be used to climb, swing and create bridges amongst other things in order to traverse obstacles and solve puzzles.

The game is alright, not too long but sweet and unique. It is a 2d puzzle game that you are a yarn creature and use your own yarn to solve puzzles. The puzzles are simple and neat. The first two levels are a little slow but I feel the game gets better and I kinda finished the rest of levels in one sitting.

Unraveled is a beautiful platformer with all the feels. The game is gorgeous, like a playable Pixar movie. Yarns is incredibly emotive and lifelike. The motion capture and animation are amazingly well done. This game is every bit current gen.
A cutesy puzzle platformer for the young and old. Not really my thing but I enjoyed what I played of it none the less.
Yarny???? more like Yawny. What a let down and boring experience, the only thing going for it is the lovely graphics, other than that, its a let down.......
Now this is what I call a "good game" EA.

Only a word it's amazing , i can't believe that's game 78 be metascore really more worth for game, the remember childhood with amazing graphics and gameplay that is 2D be dust in atmosphere all are feature's game , the cold of winter & blossom and flower of spring & summer heat & the fall of leaf in autumn well can be felt on game, Only a word it's amazing .

As much visually impressive as it is completely forgettable gameplay-wise, unravel is going to end up in 2016 disappointing games list for sure. Stunning visuals and nice soundtrack do not compensate for complete lack of inspiration in puzzle/platforming design

What a great little game with some really nice Scandinavian settings (and mindset) alongside some great game dynamics. Odd that some review sites seem to completely miss the point or lack any emotional connection...
Such an enjoyable game. It's beautifully made with such detail that on an aesthetic level it almost treads a line between game and art, together with the sound design it's quite therapeutic to play.

From the moment I first saw the trailer for this game, I was interested. Just the look and polish of the graphics was fascinating to me. I love a good challenging puzzle game. And this fits the bill almost perfectly. With a character (yarny), that literally unravels as you move, this is a clever new mechanic (to me anyway), that creates fiendish puzzles and a very new type of game. I live in the UK, and paid only thirteen pounds for it, which is a complete bargain, in my book!!! I have very few complaints, the only niggles were occasional glitches, but nothing game breaking. Overall thoroughly enjoyable experience at a bargain price!!!

Juego cargado de sentimentalismo , un apartado gráfico impresionante y una historia que nos demuestra mas allá de los que nos muestra, realmente es un respiro fresco de lo que se ve últimamente, al terminarlo deseaba que el juego hubiera durado más, y ése es uno de sus fallos, el juego dura muy poco cuando realmente hubiera podido abarcar un poco mas de mapas, de resto a sido uno de los juegos que mas he disfrutado en éste año. Si quieren jugar a algo distinto , éste es su juego.
Unravel is a visually striking and heartfelt game that will leave you with a knot in your throat, if not tears in your eyes.

Unravel is a visual and musical masterpiece of indie video games, and a real proof that low-budget projects can overcome more powerful productions in economic terms if created with passion and common sense.

Unravel has no plot. In any case, it is not as meaningful as in most games. Instead, the game will reveal to you the beauty of nature. He will show how brutally human can handle this flora and fauna to destroy. How much depends on rain or wind. You will appreciate this warm heat from the stove which heats your feet, while behind the window everything that is alive struggles for survival.

title: Until Dawn
summary: When 8 friends become trapped on a remote mountain getaway gone wrong, things quickly turn sinister and they start to suspect they aren’t alone. Gripped by fear and with tensions in the group running high, you’ll be forced to make snap decisions that could mean life or death for everyone involved. Every choice you make while playing as each of the eight friends – even the seemingly trivial ones – will carve out your own unique story.
reviews: Until Dawn is a damn near perfect game, which just breathes horror on every level. The game puts you in control of a group of teens and terrifies you while doing so. This is a must have if you own a PlayStation 4.

Until Dawn is everything that Quantic Dream games have tried to be – unsuccessfully – for the past decade. It emulates horror movies while demonstrating a clear understanding of what makes those movies work, its focus on consequence is nervewracking and intricate, and its story is silly but strongly delivered. It’s the best David Cage game not made by David Cage, and it’s the best interactive horror flick you’ll play.
Until Dawn succeeds on so many levels of story telling and creates this amazing interactive survival horror experience.
If you are opened minded to a non-traditional gaming experience and enjoy horror games and/or movies, I would highly recommend giving Until Dawn a try.

While Until Dawn lacks complex gameplay, it counters with compelling characters, astounding visuals, and a thought provoking storyline. A masterful fusion of art forms, Until Dawn is a refreshingly self-aware experience that no thriller fan should pass up.

Designed by passionate horror fans, Until Dawn is a love letter to the era of slasher movies, a game fully aware of its ridiculousness that asks players to join it for one heck of a ride. Whether you play it by yourself or with a friend or two, this is an adventure worth partaking in.
One aspect of this game that I really like is the inclusion of a psychiatrist who speaks to you between chapters.
Until Dawn takes Heavy Rain's mechanics and refines them, adding a delicious horror sauce and going to town with the result. It is absolutely brilliant in every conceivable way.

Even though the gameplay elements may be a little light compared to most games, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with Until Dawn. The story kept me captivated and very few games succeed at creating such a creepy and unsettling atmosphere.

Until Dawn is a great mixture of all the cliches of the YA thriller genre, beautifully wrapped in a Heavy Rain formula. Supermassive Games did excellent work on the narrative; graphics and soundtrack are top notch, and so is the Italian voice-over.
